case_title: KRISHNA MEDICAL STORES and another vs INCOME TAX OFFICER and another
reference_no_or_id: Criminal Revisions Cases Nos. 627 and 628 and Criminal Revision Petitions Nos. 627 and 625 of 1990

accussed_details.name: KRISHNA MEDICAL STORES
allegation: Wilful attempt to evade tax under Section 276-C of Income Tax Act

accussed_details.name: Partner of KRISHNA MEDICAL STORES
allegation: False verification of returns under Section 277
Wilful attempt to evade tax under Section 276-C read with Section 278-B

complaint_summary: The petitioners were accused of evading tax by making false debit entries in the names of individuals who were not employees of the firm.
investigation_summary: The Income Tax Officer disallowed the debit entries made in the names of two brothers of the second petitioner, finding them non-employees. Appeals to higher authorities confirmed the disallowance.

judgment_summary.mens_rea: Prosecution failed to establish wilful intent to evade tax.
judgment_summary.evidence: Income-tax returns of brothers showed remuneration, accepted by authorities.
judgment_summary.convictions: Set aside due to lack of evidence of wilful intent.
judgment_summary.refund: Fine paid by petitioners to be refunded.

punishment.A-1: Fine of Rs. 1,000, in default rigorous imprisonment for one month.
A-2: Rigorous imprisonment for three months and fine of Rs. 1,000, in default rigorous imprisonment for one month.
Fine of Rs. 1,000, in default rigorous imprisonment for one month on the second charge.
punishment.A-4: Imprisonment till the rising of the court and fine of Rs. 1,000.

Decision_or_verdict: Revisions allowed; convictions and sentences set aside.
legal_arguments: Mens rea is essential for conviction under Sections 276-C, 277, and 278.
Prosecution failed to prove wilful intent or knowledge of false statements.
Income tax returns of the alleged employees were accepted by authorities.

witness_statement.Accountant: Accounts were written at the instance of A-4, not the second petitioner.

outcome.petitioners: Convictions and sentences confirmed, appeals dismissed.

key_issues: Whether the petitioners wilfully attempted to evade tax.
Whether the debit entries were made with knowledge of falsity.
Whether remuneration paid to the second petitioner's brothers was legitimate.

maxims.Mens rea: Essential element for criminal liability under tax evasion provisions.

legal_terms.Wilful: Act done with bad purpose or evil motive.

words_and_phrases.Wilful omission: Intentional exclusion of relevant entries in account books.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around alleged tax evasion by KRISHNA MEDICAL STORES and its partner. The court emphasized the necessity of proving mens rea for convictions under Sections 276-C, 277, and 278 of the Income Tax Act. The prosecution failed to establish wilful intent or knowledge of falsity in the returns filed by the petitioners. Consequently, the convictions and sentences were set aside, and fines refunded.

facts.second_petitioner: A partner of the firm and in charge of its affairs
charges: Section 278 of the Income Tax Act, 1961

trial_outcome.A-2: Found guilty under Sections 277 and 276-C read with Section 278-B.
